posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Just was wondering what your thoughts were on base AB goals for level 40 builds for combat and hybrid builds

I would have thought that a base AB of 38 would have been ok (pretty good for a spellsword even), 40 is good and 42+ great.

I'm pretty sure dungeon masters design bosses to fight level 40 characters around fighters with a BAB of 30 and an attribute modifier of +8 hitting maybe 25 to 50% of the time, but maybe some of you have DM experience or experience building areas and know better than me.

Mithdradates wrote this (admittedly 13 years ago in response to TyrTemplar's first build posting) and I think he was writing about base AB here
Mithdradates wrote (source: http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 41416.html) in May 2006:

I'll echo Grim's sentiment about droping your wisdom and raising your dexterity instead. A 32 AB is pretty low, typically you can think of ABs as follows:
<=37 low
38-40 average support character
40-42 good support character, low warrior
42-44 average warrior
>=45 good warrior.
(different builders have different scales, but this should be fairly standard)
Anyway, what do you guys think?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, just a tiny subject, then!

While I'd broadly agree with Mith's analysis, there are just so many variables to take into account. Is your build meant for party-play or as a soloist? Is it a tank, an agent of destruction, or a backstabber? (I'm only going with non-arcane/priestly builds here, btw.) By and large, though, I'd always be looking for at least 40 AB - but sometimes I've had to sacrifice 1 or 2 AB if dual-wielding - it makes me itch to do it, though. And that's when you start thinking about APR, and it's one of the reasons I like Monk so much. You can achieve up to twice as many attacks per round than any other class (assuming d-w kama), so your chances of a hit improve - particularly with a -3 progression rather than -5: so a 41/36/31/26 AB can become 39/36/33/30/27/39/36 without blinking (my numbers might be askew, btw). Which is better? It surely depends entirely on what your build concept is. Yes, of course a combat build will want the best AB it can get, but at what cost?

I'm running the risk of getting myself tied in knots with this one just now, so I'll leave it for now. To be continued...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
As a general rule of thumb Mithdradates is right.
Meaning
      a) I agree with his AB estimates
      b) you should always listen to Mithdradates

I assume you talk about PvM and not PvP here.
As for spellswords; it is hard to get any better than AB +40, but try to get as close as possible.
Clerics are a spacial case, because they can easily buff the AB to the cap.
Bards have a great AB boost from the songs and taunt.
Paladins can live with a little lower AB because of their spells. That gives room for some charisma.
Stealth characters that hit flat footed creatures generally have a lower AC to beat.
Weaponmasters should have very high AB, not only to hit ther target. They have an extended critical threat trange and want to hit with rolls within that range, I mean what use is a range from 12 to 20 if you only are able to hit on 18 or better. They also want a high AB to be able to confirm their critical threats so they actually land critical hits.
etc.etc...

If your fighter has AB +44, it means that the 4 attacks have AB +44/+39/+34/+29.  A rogue character with AB +39 typically has 3 attacks with AB +39/+34/+29. Note that only the best attack from the fighter is better. Most module builders let 3/4 BAB builds hit some too.

At the end of the day the whole discussion boils down to how the module builder designs the creatures you have to fight. A balanced module let the fighter types hit on a regular basis, even against bosses. Against mobs you may perhaps hit even with your 4th attack, at least with a half- decent roll. The module builder must also take into account what equipment will be available, so it maintains the balance.
How this balance is maintained and what level of magical items are available defines the setting you want to build for. 
When you play a module or on a PW you will soon get a feel for how things are balanced out; if a very high AB is necessary, or if AC is more important, how important saves are and what you can achieve with available equipment.

But given all this (and more) Mithdradates is right!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I will be happy to explain Stag:

The 3rd edition of Dungeons & Dragons brought with it a measure of opponents worth beyond what the basic assumption before was. 
In Advanced Dungeons & Dragons (1st/2nd edition) the only measure a DM had for assembling encounters for the party was the Hit Dice of each monster & (somewhat) it's exp worth. 
That quickly changed in when 3rd edition came along, however. Now, the system had a measurement so to say, not based solely on Hit Dice but of all abilities a monster could have & assigned a CR on each one of them.
For example, a fire giant (CR 10 in PnP) represents an encounter of average difficulty for a party of four heroes of 10th-level each. The party should be able to win against it with minimal difficulties if they play right & luck is not against them.
The system recognizes that not all encounters should be equal (it would be boring & wouldn't serve well for story-telling purposes) and it has a scale based on the difference of CR versus the party.
Thus, an easy encounter (EL, encounter level - EL is the general term used for the whole encounter & not for the individual monster, two fire giants each CR 10, should be an EL encounter of 12) is between 1-3 levels below the party's level.
And a hard encounter is between 1-3 levels above the party's level. A very hard encounter (typical for Boss monsters) could be anywhere between 4-5 levels above the party.
Finally, an almost impossible encounter should be 6-7 levels above the party's level. An encounter with EL above that is not advised for any situation.

Still with me? Good, let's proceed to solve the next questions which you will undoubtedly have:

Q: Is the CR ratings always correct? Have they been play-tested extensively?
A: No. There are too many variables here within the freedom that 3rd edition D&D gives to the players. The system is build on the assumption that a core rules party of four with 25 point-buy (NwN 1, has 30) will be facing these foes.
Adding more members to the party, allowing more points for ability generation, using more books with more powerful options, giving more treasure (as in high-magic worlds), all of them affect the general system & make it less accurate. 
Having said that, the CR system has indeed been play-tested extensively & further monster manuals are based on the numbers of the first one, so a DM can count on the CR ratings being accurate in general.
An experienced DM is assumed to make the changes to his own monsters & encounters based on his party's strength so the CR/EL system stays relevant.

Q: How this affects Neverwinter Nights though? Is the CR/EL system as accurate here as the PnP one?
No. This is a computer game & many things that are possible in PnP for both players & monsters cannot be presented here.
Abilities & situations like flying, teleporting, borrowing, overbearing, 5-foot steps, reach, difficult ground, etc. can only be "approximated" through the game's engine.
Thus, the game is solely responsible for setting its own measurement of difficulty for each one of its monsters/foes & that is why many adversaries have different CR than their PnP equivalents.
When you right-click on a monster that it has purple CR in NwN, that means the encounter should be next to impossible for you. And yet, NwN is so often wrong.
Part of this is the limitations for the monsters & part of it is also the stupid A.I which is nowhere next to equivalent to a DM being present.
Of course, this being a computer game can solve most problems by throwing more monsters at you.
